When I was a boy, puppies were something you got from the litter down the road, which otherwise would have been drowned.
Dogs had breeds, but were mostly just dogs.
People didn't use the words `mutt' or `mongrel' much because mutthood and mongreldom were the default state.
Pure breeds were only for the rich and inbred.
A couple of months ago, we started looking for a puppy, and I knew that everything had changed.
My family spent hours poring over Web sites on which breeders expected us to pay $600 or more, or rescue organizations expected us to drive 200 miles to pick up the cute puppy in the photo.
And a hundred new breeds seem to have been invented.
Rich old ladies no longer carried Pekingese; they carried a wide variety of small, yappy things with faces like large, old mushrooms.
Not just old ladies, either.
I saw a magazine cover featuring Martha Stewart holding a dog that looked like a black fungus and probably set her back several grand.
